titleStmt.title: Overview on the development of fuzzy random variables ଁ

analytic.title: Overview on the development of fuzzy random variables ଁ

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper presents a backward analysis on the interpretation, modelling and impact of the concept of fuzzy random variable. After some preliminaries, the situations modelled by means of fuzzy random variables as well as the main approaches to model them are explained. We also summarize briefly some of the probabilistic studies concerning this concept as well as some statistical applications.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Fuzzy random variables were introduced to model and analyze 'imprecisely valued' measurable functions associated with the sample space of a random experiment, when the imprecision in values of these functions is formalized in terms of fuzzy sets.

Different approaches to this concept have been developed in the literature, the most widely considered being that introduced by Kwakernaak [26,27] and Kruse and Meyer [25], and the one by Puri and Ralescu [49] (and [18]).
In this paper we recall these main approaches and refer to some of the relevant studies in Probability and Statistics involving them.

The structure of the paper is as follows: in Section 2 we present some preliminaries on the fuzzy values we will deal with; in Section 3 the two main approaches to the concept of fuzzy random variable are given and illustrated; Section 4 gathers some probabilistic results concerning fuzzy random variables; finally, Section 5 discusses statistical problems with fuzzy random variables.

div.head: Preliminaries on fuzzy values
div.p: Consider the p-dimensional Euclidean space R p and let • denote the usual associated norm. Let K(R p ) denote the class of the non-empty compact subsets of R p and let K c (R p ) be the subclass of convex sets in K(R p ).
The largest class of fuzzy values we will deal with in this paper is the following:
div.formula: F(R p ) = {U : R p → [0, 1] | U ∈ K(R p ) for all ∈ [0, 1]}
div.p: (where U denotes the -level of fuzzy set U for all ∈ (0, 1], and U 0 being the closure of the support of U , that is, U 0 = cl(supp U)). In other words, F(R p ) represents the class of the upper semicontinuous functions in [0, 1] R p with compact closure of the support.
Concerning the arithmetic of fuzzy values, the basic operations are the sum and the multiplication by scalars, which are defined as follows:
The space K(R p ) can be endowed with a semilinear structure by means of the Minkowski sum and the product by a scalar
div.formula: K + K = {k + k | k ∈ K, k ∈ K }, K = { k | k ∈ K}, for K, K ∈ K(R p ) and ∈ R.
div.p: In a similar way, F(R p ) can be endowed with a semilinear structure by means of the sum and the product by a scalar based on Zadeh's extension principle [61]. The application of this principle for elements in F(R p ) states that
div.formula: (U + V )(x) = sup y+z=x min{U (y), V (z)}, ( U )(x) = sup y=x U(y) = U( -1 x) if = 0, 1 {0} (x) if = 0,
div.p: for all U, V ∈ F(R p ) and ∈ R. Under the conditions imposed on fuzzy sets we are working with, and inspired by the results in Nguyen [40], one can prove for all ∈ [0, 1] that

whence the absence of linearity of K(R p ) with the considered operations from the set-valued arithmetic (i.e., there is no inverse for the Minkowski addition) is inherited by F(R p ) with the usual fuzzy set-valued arithmetic.
Regarding metrics between fuzzy values, we first recall the well-known Hausdorff metric on K(R p ), defined so that for any
div.formula: K, K ∈ K(R p ) d H (K, K ) = max sup k∈K inf k ∈K |k -k |, sup k ∈K inf k∈K |k -k | .
div.p: The Hausdorff metric is fundamental for the measurability of fuzzy set-valued mappings in Puri and Ralescu's definition. However, to analyze probabilistic and statistical aspects involving fuzzy random variables, other metrics have also been considered.
In this way, for the purpose of discussing some limit theorems for fuzzy random variables, the d ∞ -metric introduced by Puri and Ralescu [46,47] is defined so that for
div.formula: U, V ∈ F(R p ) d ∞ (U, V ) = sup ∈[0,1] d H (U , V ).
div.p: On the other hand, for the purpose of some inferential statistical procedures involving fuzzy random variables, the D W -metric introduced for the one-dimensional convex case by Bertoluzza et al. [1] (and recently generalized to the p-dimensional convex case by Körner and Näther [22] is defined so that for

and W and being identified with probability measures on the measurable space ([0, 1], B[0, 1]), W being associated with a non-degenerate distribution while has a distribution function which is strictly increasing on [0, 1]. Conditions for W and are imposed to guarantee D W is in fact a metric. Nevertheless, it should be noted that although W and are identified with probability measures, the distance D W and the choice of W and do not have a probabilistic meaning.

Remark 1. Sometimes the notion of fuzzy random variable has been formalized in a more general setting, either by considering a separable Banach space B instead of a Euclidean one (see, for instance, [50], or by removing the compactness assumed for variable values (see, for instance, [42,24]).

div.head: Fuzzy random variables: motivations and approaches
div.p: In the literature combining Fuzzy Logic and Probability Theory we can find several notions and models, like fuzzy information systems [44], fuzzy probabilities (see, for instance, [62,51,41] probabilistic sets [14], and so on.

Fuzzy random variables represent a well-formalized concept underlying many recent probabilistic and statistical studies involving data obtained from a random experiment when these data are assumed to be fuzzy set valued. Fuzzy Random Variables have been considered in the setting of a random experiment to model

• either a fuzzy perception/observation of a mechanism (the so-called 'original random variable') associating a real value with each experimental outcome, • or an essentially fuzzy-valued mechanism, that is, a mechanism associating a fuzzy value with each experimental outcome.

For the first situation, Kwakernaak [26,27] introduced a mathematical model which has been later formalized in a clear way by Kruse and Meyer [25]. In Kwakernaak/Kruse and Meyer's approach, a fuzzy random variable is viewed as a fuzzy perception/observation/report of a classical real-valued random variable. The model is stated as follows:
Definition 3.1. Given a probability space ( , A, P ), a mapping
div.formula: X : → F c (R)
div.p: is said to be a fuzzy random variable (or FRV for short) if for all ∈ [0, 1] the two real-valued mappings inf X : → R, sup X : → R (defined so that for all ∈ we have that X ( ) = [inf(X ( )) , sup (X ( )) ]) are real-valued random variables.

Probabilistic and statistical studies for FRVs in Kwakernaak/Kruse and Meyer's approach usually concern either 'crisp'parameters of the 'original'random variable or fuzzy-valued parameters defined on the basis of Zadeh's extension principle. More precisely, Kruse and Meyer [25] have defined Definition 3.2. If (X) is a real-valued parameter of a random variable X : → R associated with the probability space ( , A, P ), and E( , A, P ) denotes the class of all possible 'originals' of a FRV X : → F c (R) associated with ( , A, P ), then the induced fuzzy parameter of X corresponds to
div.formula: (X ):R → [0, 1] such that for all t ∈ R (X )(t) = sup X∈E( ,A,P ) | (X)=t inf ∈ {X ( )(X( ))}.
div.p: As an example of an induced fuzzy parameter, we mention that if (X) = E(X|P ), then (X ) corresponds to the so-called fuzzy expected value of X which is the fuzzy set in F c (R) such that for each ∈ [0, 1]
div.formula: ( (X )) = [E(inf X |P ), E(sup X |P )].
div.p: It should be emphasized that the notion of (induced) fuzzy parameter is essentially different from the classical one, since classical parameters are involved explicitly in the expression for the distribution of the associated variable, whereas the fuzzy-valued parameters are not necessarily included in it.

Example 3.1. Consider the random experiment in which a given researcher chooses at random a conference including Fuzzy Logic within its scope and being held in the period 2004-2005. Assume that we consider the random variable X = 'perception about the registration fee of the chosen conference for EUSFLAT members'.

This situation can be modelled by means of the concept of FRV in Kwakernaak/Kruse and Meyer's approach. Thus, the probability space corresponds to ( , A, P ): = {conferences to be held 2004 to 2005 and involving Fuzzy Logic among their covered topics}, A = P( ) = power set of and, because of the choice of the conference is made at random,
div.formula: P ( ) = 1 card( ) for all ∈ .
div.p: On the other hand, the perception of the registration fee for EUSFLAT members can be viewed as a FRV X associated with ( , A, P ) and taking on the values x 1 = 'very cheap', x 2 = 'cheap', x 3 = 'rather cheap', x 4 = 'moderate', x 5 = 'rather expensive', x 6 = 'expensive', x 7 = 'very expensive' which can be described, for instance, by means of trapezoidal fuzzy sets like those in Fig. 1.
In this example there is an underlying 'original random variable' which is
with X 0 ( ) = true registration fee for EUSFLAT members in Conference .
If, on the basis of the registration fees of conferences in , we can get the probability distribution whence the fuzzy expected value is the one represented in Fig. 2.

For the second situation to be modelled, Puri and Ralescu [49] introduced another mathematical approach. In Puri and Ralescu's approach, a fuzzy random variable is viewed as a mechanism associating a fuzzy set in F(R p ) with each experimental outcome. The model is stated as follows: Definition 3.3. Given a probability space ( , A, P ), a mapping
div.formula: X : → F(R p )
div.p: is said to be a fuzzy random variable (also called random fuzzy set, and referred to as FRV for short) if for all ∈ [0, 1] the set-valued mappings
div.formula: X : → K(R p ),
div.p: defined so that for all ∈ X ( ) = (X ( )) , are random sets (that is, Borel-measurable mappings with the Borel -field generated by the topology associated with the Hausdorff metric on K(R p )).

Klement et al. [18] have slightly modified the definition above by considering also FRVs as an extension of random sets but formalizing the measurability for F(R p )-valued mappings as the Borel-measurability with respect to the supremum metric d ∞ . As concluded by Colubi et al. [4,5] and Kim [16], this measurability condition is stronger than the one in Puri and Ralescu's definition (which is equivalent to considering the Borel-measurability with respect to the Skorokhod metric on F(R p )). In this special issue, Terán [60] gives a necessary and sufficient condition for the equivalence of the two measurability conditions. Example 3.2. Consider the random experiment in which a client of a Savings Bank is chosen.
Consider the random variable X = 'classification of the chosen client in accordance with his/her degree of aversion to investment'.

The key difference between this situation and the one in Example 3.1 is that there is no underlying exact degree of aversion to investment. The situation in this example can be modelled by means of the concept of FRV in Puri and Ralescu's approach. Thus, the probability space corresponds to ( , A, P ):
= {clients of the considered Savings Bank}, A = P( ) and, because of the choice of the client is supposed to be made at random,
div.formula: P ( ) = 1 card( ) for all ∈ .
div.p: On the other hand, the classification of clients with respect to their degree of aversion to investment can be viewed as an FRV X associated with ( , A, P ) and, for instance, taking the values x 1 = 'very low degree of aversion', x 2 = 'low degree of aversion',
x 3 = 'medium degree of aversion', x 4 = 'high degree of aversion',
x 5 = 'very high degree of aversion', which can be described, for instance, by means of S-curve fuzzy sets like those in Fig. 3.

Probabilistic and statistical studies for FRVs in Puri and Ralescu's approach usually concern parameters extending those from the set-valued case. The best known is the 'fuzzy expected value' which is defined [49] as follows: Definition 3.4. Given a probability space ( , A, P ), if X : → F(R p ) is a fuzzy random variable which is integrably bounded in the sense that d H ({0}, X 0 ) ∈ L 1 ( , A, P ), then the fuzzy expected value of X corresponds to the unique
div.formula: E(X | P ) ∈ F(R p ) such that for all ∈ [0, 1] (E(X |P )) = Aumann's integral of the random set X = {E(X|P ) | X: → R p , X ∈ L 1 ( , A, P ), X ∈ X a.s.[P ]}.
div.p: Example 3.3. Consider a probability space ( , A, P ) and a FRV X : → F c (R 2 ) whose values are truncated cones with bases centered in (0, 0), the truncation point being a real-valued random variable : → R having uniform distribution U [0,1] and the radius being also a real-valued random variable : → R having a chi-square distribution with 1 degree of freedom (see Fig. 4).
In this case, the (fuzzy) value of FRV X in is given by and, as a consequence, the -level mapping X is given by

If we now compute the Aumann expectation of the -level mapping, then (see [2,6]) it corresponds to the circle of center (0, 0) and radius 1 -, that is, the fuzzy expected value of X is the one in Fig. 5.
The two approaches for the concept of fuzzy random variable we have just recalled can be related as follows:
Proposition 3.1. Given a probability space ( , A, P ), and a mapping X :
div.formula: → F c (R),

div.head: Some probabilistic and statistical studies involving fuzzy random variables
div.p: For the last two decades many studies dealing with fuzzy random variables have been carried out. Most of them concern probabilistic aspects and results like, for instance,

• integration and differentiation of FRVs in probabilistic settings (cf. [47,32,55,12,52,53,24]); • fuzzy martingales, sub-and super-martingales (cf. [50,56,30,8,28,57]) and other stochastic processes. For a review, see also Li et al. [29].

Several authors have examined Weak and Strong Laws of Large Numbers for FRVs to support the suitability of the fuzzy expected value concept by Puri and Ralescu (in Definition 3.4) as the limit of sample means of independent and identically distributed FRVs (see, for instance, [15][16][17]). In particular, in the last years different approaches have been developed to state the Strong Law of Large Numbers for FRVs in terms of the d ∞ metric (cf. [3,35,45] and more recently [58], for a Marcinkiewicz-Zygmund type of SLLN).
Conditions and implications in Colubi et al. [3] are stated as follows:
Theorem 4.1. Let ( , A, P ) be a probability space and let
div.formula: X 1 : → F(R p ) be a fuzzy random variable such that E(d ∞ (X 1 , 1 {0} ) | P ) < ∞. If we suppose that {X n } n , X n : → F(R p
div.p: ) is a sequence of pairwise independent and identically distributed fuzzy random variables and
div.formula: S n = X 1 + • • • + X n , then lim n→∞ d ∞ 1 n S n , E(X 1 | P ) = 0 a.s.[P ],
div.p: where
div.formula: 1 n S n = 1 n (S n ) . Conversely, if {X n } n , X n : → F(B)
div.p: , is a sequence of pairwise independent and identically distributed fuzzy random variables and there exists
div.formula: U ∈ F(R p ) so that lim n→∞ d ∞ ((1/n)S n , U) = 0 , a.s.[P ], then E(d ∞ (X 1 , 1 {0} ) | P ) < ∞ and U = E(X 1 | P ).
div.p: The problem of developing limit theorems of the central type has also received attention. Nevertheless, the lack of an appropriate operational model like the normal distribution for real-valued random variables entails important differences and inconveniences. Thus, although Puri and Ralescu [48] have stated a concept of normality for FRVs, its use becomes quite limited in practice since (fuzzy) variable values are forced to have the same shape with different location. Several authors (see, for instance, [17]-where the first proofs for SLLN and CLT with FRVs were given-, and [20,23,31,43,59]) have proven Central Limit Theorems with different metrics, but the essence of the classical CLTs has been lost in some sense. Among them, Li et al. [31] have stated the following result: Theorem 4.2. Let ( , A, P ) be a probability space and let X 1 : → F(R p ) be a fuzzy random variable such that
div.formula: E([d ∞ (X 1 , 1 {0} )] 2 | P ) < ∞. If we suppose that {X n } n , X n : → F(R p )
div.p: , is a sequence of pairwise independent and identically distributed fuzzy random variables, then
div.formula: √ n d ∞ ((1/n) S n , E(X 1 | P )) converges in law (i.e., weakly) to d ∞ (Y , 1 {0} ) as n → ∞, where Y is a tight Gaussian process in l ∞ ([0, 1] × B(R p )), B(R p ) denoting the closed unit ball in R p .
div.p: In spite of many papers having been devoted to studies of Statistics in a fuzzy environment, only a small part of the literature refers to statistical problems involving FRVs. The best-known contribution is that developed by Kruse and Meyer [25] in which most of the inferences and arguments were based on the original real-valued random variables.

The studies involving FRVs in Puri and Ralescu's sense (which in fact are applicable to both approaches) have been mainly published in the last few years. Among these studies we can mention, for instance,

• statistical decision problems with fuzzy set-valued utility/loss function (cf. [9,32,54]), in which the utility/loss function has been modelled by means of FRVs; • regression analysis (especially which concerns estimation problems) in which output/input data have been modelled in terms of FRVs and parameters have been supposed to be real-or fuzzy-valued (cf. [7,21]); descriptive/probabilistic analysis of FRVs by defining measures of absolute and relative variation, like dispersion and inequality indices (e.g., [19,10,34,22]).
Asymptotic hypothesis testing methods concerning real-valued measures/parameters associated with FRVs have been developed (see, for instance, [33,34]).

On the other hand, recently some procedures to test hypothesis about the fuzzy expected value of FRVs have been established (see [20,[37][38][39]11]) by considering the Large Sample Theory for classical Statistics. The results by Körner [20] are theoretically applicable to a wide class of FRVs, although in practice the methodology cannot be directly applied. On the contrary, the results by Montenegro et al. [37][38][39], Gil et al. [11], based on the D W metric, are immediately applicable to FRVs having a finite number of different values (the so-called simple FRVs). However, the last constraint is scarcely restrictive in practice, and can be removed, as seen in [13].

As an example of an asymptotic procedure for the fuzzy expected value of an FRV we can mention the one obtained to test the two-sample problem [27] as follows: Theorem 4.3. For i ∈ {1, 2}, let ( i , A i , P i ) be a probability space, and let X i : i → F c (R) be a simple FRV associated with this probability space. Let x ik i ∈ F c (R), k i ∈ {1, . . . , r i } be the different values FRV X i takes on i , and let p i = (p i1 , . . . , p i(r i -1) ) be the vector-valued parameter representing the population distribution of X i (i.e.,
div.formula: p ik i = P { i ∈ i | X i ( i ) = x ik i }). Let E(X i |p i ) denote the population fuzzy expected value of X i .
div.p: For i ∈ {1, 2}, consider a simple random sample X i1 , . . . , X in i from X i (i.e., X i1 , . . . , X in i are independent and identically distributed, the common distribution being that of X i ). Let f n i = (f n i 1 , . . . , f n i (r i -1) ) be the vector-valued parameter representing the sample distribution of X i , and let
div.formula: X i = (1/n i )(X i1 + • • • + X in i ) denote the sample fuzzy expected value of X i .
div.p: To test at the nominal significance level ∈ [0, 1] the null hypothesis H 0 : E(X 1 |p 1 ) = E(X 2 |p 2 ) against the alternative H 1 : E(X 1 |p 1 ) = E(X 2 |p 2 ), the hypothesis H 0 should be rejected whenever
where is the 100(1 -) fractile of the linear combination of chi-square independent variables 1 2 1,1 + • • • + q 2 1,q , with 1 , . . . , q (q r 1 + r 2 -2) being the non-null eigenvalues of the (r
div.formula: 1 + r 2 -2) × (r 1 + r 2 -2) matrix B(f n 1 , f n 2 ) H([D W (X 1 , X 2 )] 2 )B(f n 1 , f n 2 ) t , where B(f n 1 , f n 2 )B(f n 1 , f n 2 ) t = [I F X (f n 1 , f n 2 )] -1 = ⎛ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎜ ⎝ n 1 + n 2 n 1 [I F X 1 (f n 1 )] -1 0 0 n 1 + n 2 n 2 [I F X 2 (f n 2 )] -1 ⎞ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎟ ⎠ , [I F X i (f n i )] -1 = [f ik i ( k i l i -f il i )], i = 1, 2, •• = Kronecker delta
div.p: and the sample Hessian matrix is given by
div.formula: H([D W (X 1 , X 2 )] 2 ) = [ h k 1 l 1 ] [ h k 1 l 2 ] [ h k 2 l 1 ] [ h k 2 l 2 ] with h k i l j = j 2 [D W (X 1 , X 2 )] 2 jf ik i jf jl j = (-1) 1-ij 2 E([f x ik i (•, •) -f x ir i (•, •)][f x jl j (•, •) -f x jr j (•, •)] | W ⊗ )
div.p: (which in fact is a matrix irrespective of the sample). Furthermore, the probability of rejecting H 0 under H 1 converges to 1 as n → ∞.
Asymptotic results in this theorem and similar ones for one-and k-sample problems are easily applicable and lead to suitable inferences when large samples are available.

For general samples, bootstrap techniques have been used to approximate the asymptotic tests above (see [36,38,11]). In this special issue González-Rodríguez et al. [13] present a summarized review on the bootstrap approximation of the asymptotic tests for general F c (R p )-valued FRVs in the one-sample case.

Montenegro and others have introduced the bootstrap methodology to deal with FRVs, and they have shown the adequacy of the bootstrap techniques in the setting of FRVs because of two arguments, namely:
• the lack of suitable operational models for the distribution of FRVs;
• the good behavior shown in the comparative studies developed in previous papers [37,38,11].

To perform bootstrap techniques and especially to compare different statistical approaches as well as to show empirically some probabilistic results, some introductory simulation studies have been developed (see [6]). Thus, by simulating some special types of FRVs studies have been carried out • either to corroborate the convergence of the arithmetic mean of the simulated values to the population fuzzy expected value of the considered FRV; • or to compare different techniques constructed to test hypotheses on parameters of FRVs (in particular, asymptotic and bootstrap methods); • or to compare the probabilities of errors and the power function of the analogue tests based on real-valued and fuzzy-valued sample information.

div.p: ଁ The research in this paper has been partially supported by the Spanish Ministry of Education and Science Grants BFM2002-01057 and BFM2002-03263. This financial support is gratefully acknowledged. The work of Dan Ralescu was also partly supported by a Taft grant, and by a Faculty Development grant from the University of Cincinnati.
